dublin_core.dcvalue: We present a study using a method able to assess tissue oxygenation taking into account the absorption and the level of scattering in myocardial tissue using a calibrated fiber optic probe With this method interindividual comparisons of oxygenation can be made despite varying tissue optical properties during coronary artery bypass grafting CABG During CABG there are needs for methods allowing continuous monitoring and prediction of the metabolism in the myocardial tissue 14 patients undergoing CABG are investigated for tissue oxygenation during different surgical phases using a handheld fiber optic spectroscopic probe with a source detector distance of less than 1 mm The probe is calibrated using a light transport model relating the absorption and reduced scattering coefficients mu a and mu s to the measured spectra By solving the inverse problem absolute measures of tissue oxygenation are evaluated by the sum of oxygenized hemoglobin and myoglobin Agreement between the model and measurements is obtained with an average correlation coefficient R2 of 0 96 Oxygenation is found to be significantly elevated after aorta cross clamping and cardioplegic infusion as well as after reperfusion compared to a baseline pUnder0 05 Tissue oxygenation decreases during cardiac arrest and increases after reperfusion
Made available in DSpace on 2020-02-06T16:53:43Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 2008-11-21
Myocardial tissue oxygenation estimated with calibrated diffuse reflectance spectroscopy during coronary artery bypass grafting.
